Package com.github.tommyettinger.digital

Class Stringf

java.lang.Object
com.github.tommyettinger.digital.Stringf
public final class Stringf extends Object
A limited polyfill for String.format() where the platform doesn't provide it, such as on GWT or TeaVM. This supports format(String, Object...) with only some of the formatting options in the actual, much-larger Formatter class: %% , %s , %d , %f , %x , %X, and some precision options, such as %.3f . Scientific notation is not yet supported, though it could be added in. Some features will probably never be added here, like time and date formatting.
Some useful features here are that appendf(StringBuilder, String, Object...) allows reusing a StringBuilder, printf(String, Object...) acts like a method on OutputStream (which is typically not provided if String.format() isn't), and printfn(String, Object...) acts like printf() with a newline like println().

  • Method Details

    • appendf

      public static StringBuilder appendf(String fmt, Object... args)
      Uses the given args to fill out the format String fmt, puts that in a new StringBuilder, and returns that.
      Parameters:
      fmt - the format String; only supports a subset of Formatter options
      args - the parameters to fmt, as an array or varargs
      Returns:
      a new StringBuilder containing the formatted text

    • appendf

      public static StringBuilder appendf(StringBuilder sb, String fmt, Object... args)
      Appends the given format String fmt using the given args, if any, to sb, and returns sb after changing it.
      Parameters:
      sb - will be modified in-place
      fmt - the format String; only supports a subset of Formatter options
      args - the parameters to fmt, as an array or varargs
      Returns:
      sb, after modifications

    • format

      public static String format(String fmt, Object... args)
      Uses the given args to fill out the format String fmt, and returns that as a String
      Parameters:
      fmt - the format String; only supports a subset of Formatter options
      args - the parameters to fmt, as an array or varargs
      Returns:
      a new String containing the formatted text

    • printf

      public static void printf(String fmt, Object... args)
      Uses the given args to fill out the format String fmt, and prints that to stdout. This is comparable to java.io.PrintStream#print.
      Parameters:
      fmt - the format String; only supports a subset of Formatter options
      args - the parameters to fmt, as an array or varargs

    • printfn

      public static void printfn(String fmt, Object... args)
      Uses the given args to fill out the format String fmt, and prints that to stdout with an appended newline. This is comparable to java.io.PrintStream#println.
      Parameters:
      fmt - the format String; only supports a subset of Formatter options
      args - the parameters to fmt, as an array or varargs
